items.item_details:
RESOLUTION
IN CELEBRATION OF BILL AND GAY KRAUSE
AND
THE KRAUSE CENTER FOR INNOVATION
AT FOOTHILL COLLEGE
					 
Resolution #2013-37
					 
Whereas, Gay and Bill Krause for the past 15 years have been great friends and supporters of the Foothill-De Anza Community College District; and
					 
Whereas, Bill and Gay Krause have created an oasis of professional development for educators in the Krause Center for Innovation at Foothill College; and
					 
Whereas, Gay and Bill Krause have successfully nurtured the Krause Center from its start-up phase into a dynamic center of teaching and learning that is recognized nationally and internationally; and
					 
Whereas, Gay Krause has drawn on her deep experience as a teacher and administrator to provide leadership and vision as the center’s founding executive director; and
					 
Whereas, Bill Krause has shared his expertise as an iconic Silicon Valley executive to help achieve the center’s vision of transforming teaching practices through the use of technology; and
					 
Whereas, the Krause Center has trained more than 14,000 teachers since it opened in the year 2000; and
					 
Whereas, these teachers have used the knowledge they gained at the Krause Center to motivate and challenge hundreds of thousands of Silicon Valley students to engage in deep learning; and
					 
Whereas, thanks to the leadership and support of Bill and Gay Krause, the center has continued to evolve and expand to include specialized training for middle school mathematics teachers and customized training for teachers in the Philippines; and
					 
Whereas, the Krause Center for Innovation brings together the public resources of the Foothill-De Anza Community College District and private resources contributed by the Krauses and other donors; and 
					 
Whereas, a recent commitment of $3.5 million to the Foothill-De Anza Foundation from The Krause Foundation will secure the legacy of the Krause Center for Innovation for years to come; and
					 
Whereas, that commitment includes support for innovative educational programs for students at Foothill and De Anza colleges; now, therefore, be it
					 
Resolved, that the Board of Trustees of the Foothill-De Anza Community College District expresses its deep appreciation and respect for the leadership of Bill and Gay Krause in support of improving teaching and learning for future generations of students at Foothill and De Anza colleges and through the Krause Center for Innovation.
					 
PASSED AND ADOPTED this 4th day of November, 2013.
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Chancellor Linda Thor recommends approval of resolution 2013-37 in celebration of Bill and Gay Krause and the Krause Center for Innovation at Foothill College.
items.item_text: Resolution in Celebration of Bill and Gay Krause and the Krause Center for Innovation at Foothill College
items.item_text_raw: Resolution in Celebration of Bill and Gay Krause and the Krause Center for Innovation at Foothill College

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District has miscellaneous bookstore furniture, cabinets and displays at the off-site De Anza College Shipping and Receiving warehouse that is of no further use to the District. It has been determined that the furniture, cabinets and displays are old and at the end of life or are in such poor condition that they are unusable. District staff estimates the value of this furniture to be less than $100.00 in the aggregate.
	 
California Education Code 81452(c) provides that if the governing board, by a unanimous vote of those members present, finds that the property is of insufficient value to defray the costs of arranging a sale, the property may be disposed of in the local public dump on order of any employee of the District empowered for that purpose by the board.
	 
District staff will dismantle the items and recycle or dispose of the components appropriately.
 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director, Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Eric Olague, Buyer, Purchasing Services
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Make a finding that the items are of insufficient value to defray the costs of arranging a sale and authorize the Director of Purchasing Services to recycle or dispose of the items in the local public dump.
items.item_text: Recycle and Dispose of De Anza College Bookstore Surplus Property
items.item_text_raw: 3. Recycle and Dispose of De Anza College Bookstore Surplus Property

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District owns two Zep Solvent Parts Cleaners that have been determined by the De Anza Automotive Technology Department to be of no further use by the District.  
	 
Education Code 81450.5 provides that a community college district may donate any personal property belonging to the District if the District determines that the property is no longer required for school purposes provided that the property is donated to a school district, a community college district, or a public entity.
	 
The Fremont Union High School District (Fremont High School) has evaluated the solvent parts cleaners and found them to be acceptable for use by their school district and would like to receive them as a donation (see attached letter). Therefore, it is recommended that the solvent parts cleaners be donated to the Fremont Union High School District. 
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director, Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Eric Olague, Buyer, Purchasing Services
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: In accordance with Education Code 81450.5, authorize the Director of Purchasing Services to make a donation of the equipment described herein to the Fremont Union High School District.
items.item_text: Donation of Surplus District Automotive Parts Cleaners
items.item_text_raw: 4. Donation of Surplus District Automotive Parts Cleaners

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
  
  
 The District owns miscellaneous surplus property that has been determined to be of no further use to the District (see attached Surplus Disposal Forms, 8 pages). The estimated aggregate market value of the surplus property is less than $5,000.00. 
	 
California Education Code 81452(a) provides that if the governing board by a unanimous vote of those members present, finds that the property, whether one or more items, does not exceed in value the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), the property may be sold by any employee of the District empowered for that purpose by the board. 
	 
Purchasing Services will call for competitive bids on the Public Surplus website and sell the items to the highest responsive bidders. Proceeds will be deposited to the District’s general fund. 
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director, Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Eric Olague, Buyer, Purchasing Services
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Make a finding that the surplus property does not exceed $5,000.00 in value and authorize the Director of Purchasing Services to sell the items in accordance with Education Code 81452(a).
items.item_text: Sale Of Miscellaneous District Surplus Property
items.item_text_raw: 5. Sale Of Miscellaneous District Surplus Property

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Pursuant to Education Code section 76361, the associated students at both Foothill and De Anza College passed measures to assess enrolled students an Eco Pass fee for using public transportation (VTA) in Santa Clara County. Under the authority of the permissive Code, see Ed. Code section 70902(a)(1), the Board has the authority to wholly or partially exempt certain categories of students, so long as those exemptions are not discriminatory on their face or in their impact. Administrators at both campuses have investigated and determined that an additional seven categories of fee exemption should be adopted, as they are needed by the described students, and are not discriminatory in description or in actual impact. Based on this authority, both Foothill and De Anza College request the Governing Board to create an exemption from Eco Pass Transportation Fees for the following categories of students:
HOPE students 
Middle College students
Veteran’s College Fee Waiver recipients
Apprenticeship students
Students who take classes 100% online and do not reside in Santa Clara County
Students who co-enroll at both campuses (those students will pay the eco pass transportation fee at one campus)
Concurrent enrollment students—Foothill College only
Submitted by:
Denise Swett, Bernata Slater, Letha Jeanpierre, Kevin McElroy
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Foothill Administration recommends that the Board adopt the resolution to allow colleges to exempt the listed above categories of students from assessing the Eco Pass Transportation fee.
items.item_text: Eco Pass Transportation Fee - Student Exemption
items.item_text_raw: 7. Eco Pass Transportation Fee - Student Exemption

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Foothill seeks board approval for application to the State Chancellor's Office for the associate degree for transfer. This degree meets the requirements established by the State Chancellor’s Office in response to SB 1440 to establish a means of simplifying student movement within and between the segments of higher education in California.
	 
Computer science courses provide a combination of theoretical study and practical application.  Core areas include hardware, software, algorithms, operating systems, languages and data structures.  Specialized topics include mobile apps, graphics programming, open source, networking and quantum computation.
	 
The Associate in Science Degree in Computer Science for Transfer will prepare students to transfer to local California State Universities (CSUs). Students who complete the Associate in Science in Computer Science for Transfer Degree will be ensured preferential transfer status to local CSUs as Computer Science majors and/or majors in related disciplines. The Associate in Science in Computer Science for Transfer Degree requirements will fulfill the lower division major requirements at many local CSUs.  Students are advised, however, to meet with a counselor to assess the course requirements for specific local CSUs.
	 
The new degree has been approved by Foothill's Curriculum Committee.
	 
Submitted by:
Judy Miner
Additional contact names:
Kimberlee Messina, Isaac Escoto
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Foothill Administration recommends approval of the Associate in Science in Computer Science for Transfer Degree (AS-T) Program.
items.item_text: Foothill - Approval of Associate in Science Degree in Computer Science for Transfer
items.item_text_raw: 9. Foothill - Approval of Associate in Science Degree in Computer Science for Transfer

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Foothill seeks board approval for application to the State Chancellor's Office for the associate degree for transfer. This degree meets the requirements established by the State Chancellor’s Office in response to SB 1440 to establish a means of simplifying student movement within and between the segments of higher education in California.
	 
Studio Art is the study of visual art through hands-on studio experience and understanding of the history of art. The Associate in Arts in Studio Art for Transfer Degree is a solid preparation for transfer majors to local California State Universities (CSUs) in various areas in Studio Art. The Associate in Arts in Studio Art for Transfer Degree includes core foundation level drawing, two-dimensional and three-dimensional design and art history. The Associate in Arts in Studio Art for Transfer Degree also offers a wide variety of beginning level studio art electives including painting, figure and head and hand drawing, ceramics and ceramic sculpture, print arts, digital arts and photography.
	 
Students who complete the Associate in Arts in Studio Art for Transfer Degree will be ensured preferential transfer status to local CSUs for Studio Art majors and majors in related disciplines.  The Associate in Arts in Studio Art for Transfer Degree requirements will fulfill the lower division major requirements at many local CSUs.  Students are advised, however, to meet with a counselor to assess the course requirements for specific local CSUs and to validate which CSUs are considered local. 
	 
The new degree has been approved by Foothill's Curriculum Committee.
	 
Submitted by:
Judy Miner
Additional contact names:
Kimberlee Messina, Isaac Escoto
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Foothill Administration recommends approval of the Associate in Arts in Studio Arts for Transfer Degree (AA-T) Program.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Foothill seeks board approval for application to the State Chancellor's Office for the associate degree for transfer. This degree meets the requirements established by the State Chancellor’s Office in response to SB 1440 to establish a means of simplifying student movement within and between the segments of higher education in California.
	 
Physics, the fundamental science, conceptualizes the basic principles of the universe and establishes the foundation for astronomy, chemistry and geology. The beauty of physics lies in a small number of powerful concepts which expand our view of the world around us and which lead to many engineering applications from which we derive many benefits.
	 
The Physics Department prepares students to advance to the next step towards a career in science, industry, or education.  Students awarded an Associate in Science in Physics for Transfer Degree will know the basic principles of physics and be able to apply their knowledge to practical, theoretical, and experimental problems. Students who complete the Associate in Science in Physics for Transfer Degree will be ensured preferential and seamless transfer status to local CSUs for Physics majors and majors in related disciplines.  The requirements will fulfill the lower division major requirements at many local CSUs.  Students are advised, however, to meet with a counselor to assess the course requirements for specific local CSUs and to validate which CSUs are considered local.
	 
The new degree has been approved by Foothill's Curriculum Committee.
	 
Submitted by:
Judy Miner
Additional contact names:
Kimberlee Messina, Isaac Escoto
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Foothill Administration recommends approval of the Associate in Science in Physics for Transfer Degree (AS-T) Program.

items.item_text_raw: 11. Foothill - Approval of Associate in Science Degree in Physics for Transfer

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Foothill seeks board approval for application to the State Chancellor's Office for the associate degree for transfer. This degree meets the requirements established by the State Chancellor’s Office in response to SB 1440 to establish a means of simplifying student movement within and between the segments of higher education in California.
	 
The Associate in Arts in Geography for Transfer Degree prepares students to transfer to California State Universities (CSUs).  Students who complete the Associate in Arts in Geography for Transfer Degree will be ensured preferential transfer status to CSUs as Geography majors and majors in related disciplines. The Associate in Arts in Geography for Transfer Degree requirements will fulfill the lower division major requirements at many CSUs.  Students are advised, however, to meet with a counselor to assess the course requirements for specific local CSUs and to validate which CSUs are considered local.
  
The Associate in Arts in Geography for Transfer Degree will enable students to develop a strong foundation in spatial thinking and spatial reasoning and will also offer a wide variety of elective courses in Geography and other related fields for students to develop a broad knowledge base of human behavior.  In addition, students will develop strong critical thinking, communication, and problem-solving skills that will prepare them for the requirements of upper division course work.
	 
The new degree has been approved by Foothill's Curriculum Committee.
	 
Submitted by:
Judy Miner
Additional contact names:
Kimberlee Messina, Is
Is backup provided?
Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
At the request of the Audit and Finance Committee, the topic of prudent or best-practice district general fund reserve levels was placed on the September 12, 2013, committee meeting agenda for discussion.
	 
Committee Chair Swenson agreed to take the summary of the discussion by the Audit and Finance Committee to the next available Board of Trustees meeting as an agenda item to be reviewed and discussed by the full Board of Trustees.
	 
The Audit and Finance Committee has recommended that the Board of Trustees review the current board policy and practice regarding maintaining general fund reserves to assure the district has fiscally prudent policy and practices in place to best protect against unforeseen revenue decline or unanticipated required expenditures.
	 
Submitted by:
Kevin McElroy
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes

Revised board policy 2310 (formerly 9125) concerning regular governing board meetings is presented for review and first reading. The recommended revisions add language addressing Education Code and Government Code notice, meeting location, and accessibility requirements and bring the policy into alignment with the language and numbering system of the Community College League of California's (CCLC) Policy and Procedure Service. Added language is indicated on the attachment by bold, underlined text, while deleted text is represented by strikethrough. 
	 
The Chancellor's Advisory Council approved the revised board policy electronically by consensus on October 18, 2013. The policy will be presented for approval of the Board of Trustees at the December 9, 2013, meeting.
	 
Submitted by:

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District is in need of a local agency dispatch center to provide Law Enforcement Dispatching Services for the Foothill-De Anza Community College District.  
	 
The District Purchasing Services Department prepared bid documents and incorporated technical specifications jointly written with the Director of District Safety and Security in order to invite bids for a two-year contract with up to three additional one-year option periods. 
	 
The bid was advertised on September 24, 2013, and October 2, 2013.  The “Invitation to Bid” was sent to eighteen (18) agencies, and posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  On October 18, 2013, Purchasing Services staff publicly opened and read the bid.  
	 
Only one agency submitted a bid, San Jose State University (SJSU).  The total cost for the Law Enforcement Dispatching Services submitted by SJSU is $150,000 annually.  San Jose State University currently provides these services to the district and the cost is identical to the current contract amount.  The price will remain firm for two years with an escalation clause not to exceed three percent for the remaining option years.  
	 
District’s Safety and Security Budget will fund the annual Law Enforcement Dispatching Services contract.  
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services, ext. 6166
Additional contact names:
Ron Levine, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Authorize the Director of Purchasing Services to execute an agreement with San Jose State University pursuant to the prices, terms, and conditions set forth in Bid 1673 for an amount of $150,000 annually for the first two years, with an option to renew for three additional one-year periods.
items.item_text: Authorize award of a contract pursuant to Bid Document 1673, Law Enforcement Dispatching Services (ACTION)
items.item_text_raw: 23. Authorize award of a contract pursuant to Bid Document 1673, Law Enforcement Dispatching Services (ACTION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
De Anza College currently provides cable television service via a coaxial cabling distribution infrastructure system. The coaxial cable plant is ~25 years old and is in a semi-functioning state. The Campus also has a widely distributed fiber backbone plant, installed in phases over the past 10-15 years, which will be leveraged as part of this project. 
	 
This project upgrades the Campus' distribution infrastructure system to be compatible with Comcast's modern digital television service, including both forward and reverse path signaling. The work of this project shall include a fully integrated and upgraded distribution infrastructure system to each building identified. 
	 
Smith Fause McDonald, Inc. prepared the construction documents and a complete set of all bid documents are on file in the Purchasing Services Department.
	 
Bid #1664-282 was legally advertised on September 10 and September 17, 2013.  The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builders’ exchanges, advertised in the Daily Pacific Builder, and posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  Bids were publicly opened and read on October 17, 2013 at 3:00 p.m. by Purchasing Services.  The bid results are shown below:
	 
CONTRACTOR
BASE BID AMOUNT
BASE BID AMOUNT incl. allowance
PCD
$172,538
$180,038
Cal Coast Telecom
$367,870
$375,370
	 
The lowest responsive and responsible bidder is PCD who has successfully completed similar CATV/MATV distribution projects for other public entities such as San Francisco Unified (Galileo High School), City of Santa Clara (Central Park Library), UC Merced, and City of Pacifica (Police Headquarters).
	 
The bid price of $180,038 as submitted by PCD is within the architect’s construction estimate of $170,000 plus an allowance amount for unanticipated or unforeseen conditions and within the construction budget of $182,784. The project will be constructed with Measure E funds.
	 
Submitted by:
  Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services, Ext. 6166
Additional contact names:
  Charles Allen, Tom Armstrong, Gina Bailey
Is backup provided?
  No
items.item_recommendation: Authorize the Director of Purchasing Services, Pam Grey, to award a contract pursuant to Bid Document #1664-282, in the aggregate amount of $180,038 to PCD.
items.item_text: Award a contract pursuant to Bid #1664-282 CATV/MATV Distribution - $180,038 (ACTION)
items.item_text_raw: 25. Award a contract pursuant to Bid #1664-282 CATV/MATV Distribution - $180,038 (ACTION)

Background and Analysis:
	 
Title:  Change Order #6
Vendor:  SJ Amoroso Construction
Agreement Date:  March 3, 2013
Campus:  Foothill College
Project Number:  105
Project Name:  Modernization of Learning Support Center, Biology, and General Classrooms
Amount:  $150,994
For:
	 
Construction changes due to field conditions, architect-directed corrections and changes made by the District.  Most of the changes are responses to conditions encountered in the field, most notably for repair of roof beams found to be damaged by dry rot and replacement of roof soffit areas damaged by water intrusion.  Corrections to the architect’s design include added work at the roof to replace existing equipment openings, a revised fire sprinkler layout, and a revised window specification (which resulted in a credit to the District).  Changes made by the District included addition of a gas shutoff valve and simplification of the floor finish design (which also resulted in a credit). 
	 
This change plus all previously approved change orders amounts to 5.3% of the base contract value. 
	 
Submitted by:
Charles Allen, Executive Director, Facilities, Operations, and Construction Management, extension 6150

Art Heinrich, Director, Bond Program Management, Foothill College

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Foothill College standardized on Krueger International (KI) faculty office furniture and classroom furniture.  They identified campus specific furniture performance and service specifications that addressed concerns regarding flexibility, function, durability, quality, safety, comfort, and aesthetics.  
 
Foothill College currently requires a purchase of Krueger International (KI) classroom furniture for the Building 5600 that will be operational starting Winter Quarter 2014. The cost of the furniture is estimated not to exceed $180,000 and it will be purchased with Measure C funds.  Because the estimated cost of the furniture will exceed the current statutory bid threshold of $83,400, the District must either conduct its own bidding and award process or obtain board authorization to utilize existing contracts awarded by other public entities pursuant to Public Contract Code (PCC) 20652. 
 
Public Contract Code 20652 provides that the District may utilize contracts that have been awarded by other public entities. This process is commonly known as “piggybacking”.  The competitively bid Foundation for California Community Colleges (FCCC) contract with Kruger International (KI) is available and it includes the items required by the college. 
 
It is highly unlikely that a separate bid process conducted by our District would result in more favorable prices, terms, and conditions than the prices offered on the FCCC contract for the same goods and services.  The FCCC contracts establish discounts for furniture inclusive of specification development services, space planning services, installation drawings, shipping and delivery costs, a 15-year non-prorated parts and labor warranty, and installation services. FCCC # CAC-B-009 for administrative furniture is valid through August 23, 2014.
 
As required by the FCCC contracts, KI makes a donation of 1% for all purchases to the California Community Colleges Scholarship Endowment.  All donations that result from the District’s purchases will be allocated to the District’s account and the resulting scholarships will go to the Foothill-De Anza students.
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services, x6166
Additional contact names:
Bernata Slater, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Authorize the Director of Purchasing Services to issue a purchase order to Kruger International not to exceed $180,000 to furnish Building 5600 with office furniture pursuant to Public Contract Code 20652 and FCCC contracts CAC-B-009.
items.item_text: Authorize use of FCCC contract for Building 5600 furniture purchase pursuant to Public Contract Code 20652
items.item_text_raw: J) Authorize use of FCCC contract for Building 5600 furniture purchase pursuant to Public Contract Code 20652

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The project consist of repainting Smithwick Theater (Building 1000), and various PE Buildings (2500, 2600, and 2800); repaint and repair as needed benches, handrails and guardrails; install bird remediation netting and devices.
	 
Prodis Associates Architects prepared the construction documents and a complete set of all bid documents are on file in the Purchasing Services Department. 
	 
The bid was legally advertised to contractors on September 4, 2013, and September 11, 2013.  The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builders’ exchanges, advertised in the San Jose Post Record, and posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  A mandatory bid walk was held on September 17, 2013, and a total of Ten (10) contractors attended the walk.  Bids were publicly opened and read on October 9, 2013 in the Purchasing Services office.  Five (5) contractors submitted a bid and the bid result is summarized below:
	 
BID RESULTS
	 
Contractor
Base Bid Proposal Amount:
Calstate Construction, Inc. 
$509,333
R.C. Benson & Sons, Inc. 
$514,500
CalPacific Construction Inc.
$523,000
Fix Painting Company
$583,000
Piana Construction & Painting Inc. 
$875,750
	 
According to Public Contract Code (PCC), Section 20651(b): “The governing board shall let any contract for a public project, as defined in subdivision (c) of Section 22002, involving an expenditure of fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000) or more to the lowest responsible bidder who shall give security as the board requires, or else reject all bids.” 
	 
The bid price submitted by Calstate Construction, Inc. exceeds the architect’s estimate of $300,000 and as well as the overall project budget of $350,000.  Therefore, the District recommends that the Board reject all bids received for Bid #1665-141, Painting and Bird Remediation.   The project will be rescoped and evaluated for re-bidding. 
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services, x6166
Additional contact names:
Charles Allen, Art Heinrich, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: In accordance with PCC 20651(b), reject all bids received for Bid #1665-141, Painting and Bird Remediation at Foothill College.
